Most people reading an email are not familiar with the CEO....short answer....NO

discussion.content:
C and D

Phishing
Phishing is the most common type of social engineering attack that occurs today. But what is it exactly? At a high level, most phishing scams endeavor to accomplish three things:

Obtain personal information such as names, addresses and Social Security Numbers.
Use shortened or misleading links that redirect users to suspicious websites that host phishing landing pages.
Incorporate threats, fear and a sense of urgency in an attempt to manipulate the user into responding quickly.

questions.question_text: An employee in the finance department receives an email, which appears to come from the Chief Financial Officer (CFO), instructing the employee to immediately wire a large sum of money to a vendor. Which of the following BEST describes the principles of social engineering used? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: SELECT * FROM this means select everything from whichever table after the word FROM in the case of 1=1 just say sql injection as the answer.
The "SELECT" cmd is one of the most common SQL commands. This should be your first clue to the answer to this scenario.

SQL Injection Attack consisting of the insertion or injection of an SQL query via input 
data from the client to a web application

SQL injection is prevented through input validation and using least 
privilege when accessing a database If you see ` OR 1=1; on the exam, it’s an SQL injection

choices.C: A network scan is being done on the system
choices.A: An SQL injection attack is being attempted
choices.D: An XSS attack is being attempted

discussion.content: "This session has full read/write access to the file system and the admin console" privilege escalation

Both B and C (SQL Injection and Buffer Overflow) could have been the initial attack - but the objective was (D) privilege escalation - not A because the objective was not to merely gain control of the web domain - they wanted to go beyond that.

Is privilege escalation a sort of attack? Or the result of an attack? a buffer overflow would allow the attacker to operate in another level and gain access to the system and then the result is privilege escalation

comments.content: You have to look at the wording of the question closely and you will see the stated answer is correct
Domain hijacking is literally stealing the FQDN of a website, dont confuse this with session hijacking

discussion.content: I Think A is the best answer..

questions.question_text: A penetration testing team deploys a specifically crafted payload to a web server, which results in opening a new session as the web server daemon. This session has full read/write access to the file system and the admin console. Which of the following BEST describes the attack?

comments.content: when you say you picked both A and B, does this mean the ordering of the answers is the same?

discussion.content:
This question was on the test. Jan, 24, 2020. The good news is, it had two options to select, 
and Yes, I picked both A and B.
Too bad Faraday Cage is not listed as an option on this question haha.
Is the answer saying that it better to have an unencrypted and unlocked sensitive phone as long as there is remote wipe set up on it?

...doesn't it seem like D) biometics would make sense? An attacker would literally need access to your body parts to access the data. So unless your phone was taken by a serial killer or kidnapper who has access to your body parts and your device the phone should be safe??
sensitive , concerned , prevent , best = wipe

Crappy question tbh. The scenario can pan out like this;

A device gets lost/left on the bus whilst the user is on lunch. The user does not notice. Someone else picks it up and attempts to access within the guys lunch break. If it is encrypted (FDE) and requires a PIN he wouldn't get very far immediately.

It could also be the case that whoever picks up the device may disconnect it from the internet (WiFi/Cellular). Rendering the remote wipe option worthless. However, their could be profiles/settings preventing anyone changing cellular. But then assuming again that this is a mobile device (iPhone/Samsung, etc) someone could just pop the SIM out of the back preventing any data transmission.

Both are viable security options that cover different bases, and often you would apply both. Making us choose 50/50 is really stupid with such limited information.

If made to choose, I personally would have thought that 'B. Use FDE and require PINs on all mobile devices' is the best option here.

comments.content: I like your real world scenario. It makes sense.

discussion.content: remote wipe is a better choice

I would go with FDE. Chances are you wont realise a device is lost straight away so device is vulnerable between actually loosing it and realising that its lost. FDE will protect the data at all times and only those with correct credentails will be able to access it. Once it's been determined that the device is in fact lost (potentially some time after loosing it) then I'd go with remote wipe.

comments.content: maybe because the phone may contain a PII so the best answer is wipe rather than full full DE

discussion.content: The was another question on topic 1 has the same thing but the other one was asking about laptop and the answer was FDE. When I saw this question I said it easy the answer is FDE but it is not . I don't know if I have to trust this answer or what I believe is the right answer .
A and B look good

"If the mobile device is stolen" what would protect the data? Obviosly FDE. 
Remote wipe would be an option as well but that would be AFTER the theft.

On exam if you have to chose one option, it would be B. If two options than both A n B

I think you can select two answers for this question. But if not then remote wipe is only a “best effort” attempt, so if the mobile signal is out of range then the data can’t be wiped and will get compromised. However with FDE and a pin we will be safe if the device is stolen.
It's best to remotely wipe the phone if possible. Normally I'd choose FDE over remote wipe, but protecting FDE with a PIN could leave the phone vulnerable to a brute force attack.

comments.content: Remote wipe is the better choice for this question, the corporation is more concerned about the data getting accessed by others than its confidentiality.
Isn't data being accessed by others the very definition of a breach of confidentiality?
for most phones, you have to unlock the device to turn wifi on or off.
All you would need to do is wrap the phone in a Faraday fabric and bingo, no cell no WiFi no nothing.

All someone has to do when the phone is stolen is turn Wi-Fi off and Remote Wipe is no longer possible. They could then use specialised software to extract all data from the device. I can understand why CompTIA say this is the answer, but FDE and a strong PIN/Password for the device is a better option. Luckily from other comments it sounds like both answers are correct.

discussion.content: Isn't FDE a better option than 'Remote Wipe' when a device is lost or stolen?
the wiping method and FDE method are very important info for judgement

choices.D: Require biometric logins on all mobile devices
choices.A: Initiate remote wiping on lost mobile devices
choices.C: Use geolocation to track lost devices
choices.B: Use FDE and require PINs on all mobile devices

questions.question_text:
A corporation is concerned that, if a mobile device is lost, any sensitive information on the device could be accessed by third parties. Which of the following would
BEST prevent this from happening?

choices.C: Have the employee surrender company identification.
choices.A: Obtain a list of passwords used by the employee.
choices.D: Have the employee sign an NDA before departing.
choices.B: Generate a report on outstanding projects the employee handled.

questions.question_text: A company is terminating an employee for misbehavior. Which of the following steps is MOST important in the process of disengagement from this employee?

discussion.content:
Answer: C
Explanation:
NDA is signed prior hiring, reports are not the most important. Neither is obtain passwords because admin
should be able to reset the passwords anyway.

it should be something do with offboarding.
I go for C
if he doesn't want to sign the NDA, what are they going to do to him? fire him? he is already fired. So it can't be an answer.

Think about security types. If its a large organisation, the ID Badge would still alow them access into the premesis unless its blacklisted or handed back. The question doesn't state what access they have to data, so we can't assume they even have any, whereas all employees would need physical access to the premesis.

The Answer is C 
Non-disclosure agreement is used when onboarding or about to start a project .

From textbook, "It's common to remind employees of an existing NDA during an exit interview." That means that NDAs are signed before - whether during a job extension or when first hired. Most wouldn't even sign an NDA if they are being fired anyways.

It is C.
NDA aspects are processed when you enter an firm by the contract or an seperate addition.

comments.content: ganitor? WTH is this? I want to apply

discussion.content:
What if he was a ganitor :-). What would an NDA do ? 
It is company identification. You sign NDA when you interview and while you are employeed. So it is an implicit NDA :-).

comments.content: It doesn't specify what kind of employee, we don't know if it's janitor like Basem mentioned or someone like an IT Project Manager. In the govt sector they make sure you relinquish your prox badge/ID badge before you leave the premises.

Nope – you are not required, in any state, to sign a non-disclosure agreement (NDA) when leaving your employment. ... Therefore, an NDA just provides a company with more proof in court of the confidential relationship. With that said, don't rush to disclose or use any trade secrets before you know your rights
An NDA is signed at the beginning of employment, not at the end.
In my experience NDAs are done when you begin working with a company. But the company IDs are important since they can provide access etc
I only signed an NDA one time when leaving an that was to get a buyout package but if your terminated you probably wouldnt get that and they cant force you to sign out if you are being terminated

discussion.content: Why not D? Would the brain of this person forget everything he/she saw on the intranet?
